item.title: Marvel Cosmic Invasion Review
item.content:encoded:
Depending on who you talk to, beat ‚Äòem ups are either repetitive, button-mashy coin munchers or a deceptively simple vehicle for absolute combat mastery. Me? I‚Äôm in the latter camp. But how do you get people who aren‚Äôt sickos like myself interested? How do you lure them into taking the first steps down Sicko Road? This year‚Äôs Absolum tried by merging a mechanically excellent beat ‚Äòem up with a middling roguelite. Marvel Cosmic Invasion developer Tribute Games ‚Äì the cats behind Shredder‚Äôs Revenge, the best TMNT game since Turtles in Time‚Äì takes a different approach. It looks to the Marvel vs. Capcom fighting games of old and asks one of the boldest questions I‚Äôve seen a beat ‚Äòem up pose in a New York minute: what if it was a tag game where you controlled multiple heroes? The answer, as it turns it, rules, even if the actual execution of Cosmic Invasion doesn‚Äôt quite live up to that concept.

I‚Äôll be real with y‚Äôall; I‚Äôm not a Marvel guy. My dad‚Äôs into comics, and he got me into them, but DC was always his bag (he owns every Wonder Woman comic ever published, and no, that‚Äôs not an exaggeration), so I‚Äôm a DC kid at heart with a soft spot for indie comics. But I love the weirder parts of Marvel, especially the million conflicting X-men timelines and the cosmic stuff. It‚Äôs not the most popular thing Marvel publishes (that is and always will be Spider-Man, though X-men is no slouch), but it‚Äôs the most interesting. Give me that over the MCU stuff any day.

Marvel Cosmic Invasion Screenshots

If the title didn‚Äôt give it away, that‚Äôs what Marvel Cosmic Invasion is about. The story here is real simple, almost like it has been ripped straight from the pages of a multi-issue event series. Big Bad Annihilus‚Äôs Annihilation Wave (listen, it‚Äôs comic books, okay?) is sweeping the galaxy! All life hangs in the balance! So it‚Äôs up to a rag-tag assortment of Marvel heroes, whether Earthborn or cosmic in origin, to bring him down. That‚Äôs all you gotta know. And you know what? It works.

A lot of it comes down to the team of 15 heroes that Tribute Games has assembled. Yeah, you‚Äôve got the icons, the regulars who absolutely, positively accept-no-substitutes gotta be there. You know the ones: Storm, Wolverine, Spider-Man, Captain America. Then you‚Äôve got cats that were B-listers before the movies elevated them to prominence: Black Panther, Iron Man, Rocket Raccoon, She-Hulk, Nova, Phoenix, Venom. And then there are the weird and wacky inclusions. Thor isn‚Äôt here; instead, you get Beta Ray Bill. Real ones know. How do you feel about Cosmic Ghost Rider? Then there‚Äôs my girl Phyla-Vell. Oh, and because this is cosmic Marvel, the Silver Surfer is also here, and he is caked up. To the Silver Surfer degenerate at Tribute Games: I see you, and I appreciate you.

Everyone looks stunning because the spritework is absolutely gorgeous.

But the reality is that everyone here looks stunning because the pixel art spritework is absolutely gorgeous. Whether it‚Äôs Phyla-Vell‚Äôs hair blowing gently in the wind, how Wolverine always looks like a coiled spring, or the subtle transformations that sometimes reveal Eddie Brock beneath the symbiote as Venom, Cosmic Invasion captures the essence of these characters, right down to their voices. Go ahead and watch one the videos on this page, tell me that doesn‚Äôt sound exactly like the way Wolverine or Storm or Iron Man sound in your head. True believers, the vibe is immaculate.

Structurally, Cosmic Invasion is a pretty standard beat ‚Äòem up. Not counting the tutorial, there are 15 stages, including old Marvel standbys like New York City, Wakanda, the Savage Land, and Genosha, as well as more exotic environs like Fort Galactus, each with a fun little sub-description (Genosha‚Äôs is Heavy Metal; the Savage Land‚Äôs is Rumble in the Jungle). Stage selection is mostly a straight line, but occasionally the path will split before reconverging and you‚Äôll have to complete both branches before moving on.

Levels themselves are good but unremarkable beat ‚Äòem up fare with the occasional environmental hazard. There is a collectible to find to liven things up, as well as three challenges in each stage ‚Äì two are hero specific, such as defeating a certain number of enemies with a certain character‚Äôs special attack, while the final one is related to the stage itself. All of this is good: the challenges encourage you to use new characters and learn the intricacies of each arena, and stages are well-designed, snappy (each one takes around 10-15 minutes), and visually distinct in cool ways ‚Äì you‚Äôd never mistake Savage Lands for Klyntar or Genosha ‚Äì but nothing here is going to redefine your expectations for what a beat ‚Äòem up can be.

What makes Cosmic Invasion special is its characters. Up to four people can play Cosmic Invasion at once, each controlling two characters, and it‚Äôs impressive how different each character is, even if they might not feel that way at first. Take Nova and Iron Man; sure, both of their unique attacks are ranged energy blasts, but Nova‚Äôs can pass through and hit multiple targets at once. Iron Man‚Äôs don‚Äôt. Nova‚Äôs special attack is an energy field that only hits foes at close range, while Iron Man‚Äôs giant, Marvel vs. Capcom 2-esque laser can hit anyone standing anywhere on-screen, but it does require you to line up your enemies and aim well.

Levels themselves are good but unremarkable beat ‚Äòem up fare.

Meanwhile, Rocket is a ranged powerhouse, but his charged heavy attack does massive damage, while Phyla-Vell‚Äôs, who is more melee focused, can stun ‚Äì and no one else has anything like her sword, which she can throw and then teleport to in order to start combos and then keep them going across the screen. Beta Ray Bill and Cap can both throw their weapons, too, but Cap‚Äôs shield returns to him automatically; Bill‚Äôs will spin in place, potentially juggling anyone unlucky enough to come into contact with it until you manually call it back. Even She-Hulk and Wolverine, both up-close-and-personal bruisers, play differently. Logan is faster and all about chaining long stabby-stab combos together, while Jen is a powerhouse who focuses on short combos that launch her victims into the air for potential follow-ups. They both have grabs, but they operate in very different ways.

Some characters have dodges, while others can block and parry if they time things right, opening up more defensive options. Characters that fly have a much easier time dealing with winged foes than those who don‚Äôt, and it‚Äôs easier for them to avoid stampedes. Everyone is a little different, and that can have a massive impact on how they play.

What‚Äôs really cool, though, are the tag team elements. You only actively control one character at a time, and you can summon your tag partner for various assists to keep laying on the hurt, opening up cool new offensive possibilities ‚Äì that could be a launcher, a standard combo, their unique ability, their metered ‚ÄúI want these guys dead‚Äù special attack, and so on. Figuring out the best combinations and how movesets interact is a lot of fun, especially since you don‚Äôt start with everyone unlocked. It‚Äôs possible to lose a character mid-level (they have separate health bars), but even then, all isn‚Äôt lost. You continue on with your remaining hero, and if you stumble upon some floor food, a time-honored beat ‚Äòem up tradition, they‚Äôll come back with a little health.

Characters also level up as you use them, gaining more health, passive abilities, and so on, encouraging you to experiment, especially in co-op. I played the whole game with my wife (a single run through the campaign took three hours), and while I think Cosmic Invasion is a good time solo, like basically every beat ‚Äòem up, it‚Äôs better with friends.

Will's Favorite Licensed Games

A list of the best licensed games unfit to print.

If this beat ‚Äòem up has any black eyes, it‚Äôs the lack of enemy variety. You‚Äôll see the same core cast of baddies a lot in Cosmic Invasion, and while that‚Äôs not a huge problem (this happens in most beat ‚Äòem ups), it can get a little old. It‚Äôs also hilariously obvious when you‚Äôre fighting a boss that will become a playable character later on because it feels like you‚Äôre fighting someone you‚Äôll be able to play later. It can lead to some really funny moments, like when we were fighting the Silver Surfer on an elevator and kept knocking him into the abyss. Eventually, he‚Äôd levitate back up to us for more, only to get knocked down again. It wasn‚Äôt bad, but it was as goofy as Rob Liefeld-drawn feet or pouches.

If you get bored of beating on Annihilus‚Äôs minions, you can head to the Vault, where you can see each hero‚Äôs progress in the Hero Lab, learn about their history and the history of your foes in the Nova Corps Files, and listen to some of Cosmic Invasion‚Äôs excellent tracks. You can also spend Cosmic Cubes you earn to unlock nodes in the Cosmic Matrix for more color palettes, hero profiles, tunes, and Nova Corps Files. It‚Äôs a cool little system, and it even doubles as a neat way to make art if you unlock the right nodes in a way that forms a pattern. I made an adorable little bug, and I‚Äôll miss him when I fill everything out and he‚Äôs gone.

Verdict

The stages themselves aren‚Äôt going to blow you away and I wish there was a more varied rogues‚Äô gallery to smack down, but Marvel Cosmic Invasion‚Äôs tag team action has the juice, and it‚Äôs a joy to dig into each character‚Äôs kit, especially in co-op. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a great beat ‚Äòem up, but it is a very good one that I‚Äôm looking forward to playing again in the years to come, and it highlights some of the more obscure (and fun) parts of Marvel‚Äôs history. If you‚Äôre not already into the genre, I doubt Cosmic Invasion will change your mind, but it‚Äôs good enough to get my Avengers assembled on a lazy Sunday, kick back, and pop some baddies in the mouth.

item.title: 'Of Course There's Going to Be' a Hitman 4, Developer IO Interactive Says
item.content:encoded:
IO Interactive is busy working on James Bond video game 007 First Light, but it has said it also has plans to release Hitman 4.

In an interview with Variety, CEO Hakan Abrak said ‚Äúof course there will be more Hitman.‚Äù But it may be some time before Hitman 4 comes out. Abrak said that any talk of a Hitman 4 announcement will have to wait until Hitman co-op arrives in World of Assassination, which continues to enjoy support via DLC from the studio.

‚ÄúSo of course there will be more Hitman,‚Äù Abrak said. ‚ÄúBut right now, I think we need to get to the other side of this year and next year you‚Äôll get more news about Hitman co-op, because I think co-op is a really, really good extension to the universe, and will introduce very interesting mechanics and combinations in World of Assassination. But we will, after that, be talking about the next Hitman ‚Äî because, of course, there‚Äôs going to be a next Hitman.‚Äù

The Hitman franchise kicked off in 2000 with Hitman: Codename 47. Hitman 2: Silent Assassin followed in 2002. Hitman: Blood Money came out in 2006, and served as the third game in the original Hitman trilogy. Hitman: Absolution followed in 2012, before Hitman, which acted as the first installment of the World of Assassination trilogy, came out in 2016. Hitman 2 followed in 2018, then Hitman 3 in 2021.

IOI has three main productions right now: ongoing work on Hitman: World of Assassination, 007 First Light, and a new fantasy IP appropriately codenamed Project Fantasy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not announced yet, exactly what it is, but it‚Äôs a multiplayer fantasy project, which is extremely ambitious and really cool and is something else than a gun in a suit,‚Äù Abrak teased. ‚ÄúSo that‚Äôs also good to have something new within the creative outlook here.‚Äù

Will Hitman 4 have to wait until all three projects are wrapped up? Abrak didn‚Äôt say, but you can see why the studio would want to return to the franchise with a brand new sequel: overall, Hitman has had more than 85 million players and over 25 million copies sold. Each more, more than a million people play Hitman, Abrak added.

007 First Light screenshots

As for 007 First Light, that‚Äôs due out March 27, 2026 (a release date that looks all the more lucrative now GTA 6 is delayed to November). In the shorter term, the latest Elusive Target arriving in Hitman World of Assassination is rap star Eminem, who recruits Agent 47 to take down his dangerous alter ego Slim Shady. The mission is live now for free on all platforms.

item.title: Arc Raiders Introduces Hilarious New Fix For Locked Room Exploits: Burn Everything
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Arc Raiders players recently discovered an exploit that allowed them to loot locked rooms without needing a keycard. Naturally, the exploit quickly became popular--and frustrating for players who didn't use it--leading Embark Studios to apply a "hot" fix to this part of the game. If you now decide to cheese your way into one of these treasure rooms, you can now expect a toasty reception inside.

Using a keycard to access one of these rooms ties into the high-risk, high-reward nature of Arc Raiders, but the exploit essentially bypasses it. Players managed to break into the room, grab valuable gear without worrying about being ambushed, and pick the location clean. This meant that players who unlocked the room properly would find it stripped bare, leading to frustration within the Arc Raiders community.

To remedy this, Embark Studios made it so that the rooms automatically activate flamethrowers when you glitch into them. Players quickly found out that they would be caught inside this deathtrap, while other players with keycards would discover a room full of loot and a freshly cremated adventurer.

Arc Raiders has been a big hit since launch, selling millions of copies and hitting a peak player count of 481,966 raiders on Steam. Embark Studios has regularly updated Arc Raiders, fine-tuning the gameplay and nerfing overpowered perks.

"Arc Raiders is an extraction shooter unlike any other, a totally unpredictable, immersive, thrilling story generator directed by the community," Mark Delaney wrote in GameSpot's Arc Raiders review.
